Key Arguments: The bill threatens freedom of speech by allowing bureaucrats to decide what constitutes misinformation and disinformation.
Definitions of misinformation and disinformation in the bill are ambiguous and open to interpretation.
The bill could lead to regulatory overreach and abuse of power by granting ACMA extensive powers.
The proposed measures may not be effective in combating misinformation and could stifle legitimate discourse.
The legislation could impose significant regulatory burdens on digital platforms, particularly affecting smaller companies and stifling innovation.
There is a lack of clarity on enforcement mechanisms, leading to potential inconsistency and uncertainty.
The government itself has been a source of misinformation, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Notable Quotes: The audacity, to think these few, could have the power to make a judgement call on what is misinformation, or what is disinformation, what is truth, or what is not truth, for another fellow Australian, is wrong.
The Government itself was the main source of mis and dis information.
Censorship is a direct attack on freedom and liberty of Australians and only further centralises power to a few with Government.
